Comment: I usually strive for a Stonewall, as it is the opening that I've studied the most.

Black's play is ideal for the Stonewall set-up.  What I don't like to see is a play by the c8 Bishop to g4, which complicates matters.  Nor do I like to see g7-g6, which blunts the power of the Stonewall Attack.
White's move makes the c1 Bishop a problem Bishop, but is part of the overall Stonewall strategy which is to build a pawn wall at c3, d4, e3 and f4.

White wants to get in c3, f4, Nf3 and 0-0.  Black's play makes White's task easy as he has yet to develop a piece.  Often, White wants to play Nb1-d2 to prevent a Knight coming in at e4 and to prepare for an eventual pawn push in the center.

White wants to get in c3, f4, Nf3 and 0-0.  Black's play makes White's task easy as he has yet to develop a piece.  Often, White wants to play Nb1-d2 to prevent a Knight coming in at e4 and to prepare for an eventual pawn push in the center.
Black still hasn't developed a piece, and this move seems to waste time.
White seizes firm control of e5, the hoped for home of the g1 Knight.
White doesn't want the Knight to come to b4
The Stonewall Formation is complete.
A waste of time.  And now the Knight is hanging.
White's development is natural.  0-0 is next.
The Bishop is "biting on granite" as the f4 pawn is well defended.
Black is dilly dallying.  He may be seeing ghosts or thinking of an ill-advised pawn push on the K-side.
Black is dilly dallying.  He may be seeing ghosts or thinking of an ill-advised pawn push on the K-side.

I'm not sure what I was thinking at the time.  An alternative is Ne5, with an opening of the f-file in the offing.  The text may be better as it develops a piece, takes control of e4 (with e3-e4 contemplated), and would be available to defend the N on e5.
All according to plan.  White has control of the b1-h7 diagonal, Black is still in the center, and Black's Bishop is "entombed."

All according to plan.  White has control of the b1-h7 diagonal, Black is still in the center, and Black's Bishop is "entombed."
How can White intensify the attack?
I'm not sure whether this move deserves a ! or a ?  It frees up the opponent's Bishop, but maybe I can get control of the a8-h1 diagonal, or get an attack going that is overwhelming.
This was probably a mistake.  Better would be to let White capture on d5 and recapture with the pawn to free the c1 Bishop.  White considers which piece is best for the recapture.
White has an overwhelming Kingside attack.
The Knight threatens little or nothing, and abandons its brethren.
Keeps the Black queen from imagining a post on h4, pins the g7 pawn.
